This method, Newton-Raphson method, is taught at GCE Advanced Mathematics (not Further Mathematics which overlaps with university mathematics ) to 17/18 year old students, not in calculus but in numerical methods. The formula is derived from first principles, including the derivative which is defined as was done by Augustine Cauchy in nineteenth century, and roots are computed using the iterative N-R formula.
The root(s) are calculated using calculator Casio fx-9860GII. Less than 10% marks are given for computation.
Newton-Raphson method breaks down if the root is very close to a stationary point.

I am not sure where I commented this, probably on the followup part 2, but it's amazing that there is most definitely an infinite family of points which cyclically follow each other,hopping around the boundary. If you pick a point which is on the boundary, within a small circle is a point which, when iterated upon once, will land near a different point near the boundary. If you follow the family of points that do this, you will be able to weed out unfavorable points (which fling off into one of the 3, 4, 5, or whatever regions that'll converge) and essentially evolve a point which will iterate and bounce around chaotically forever. Each step eliminates a huge number of points, but with an infinite number of points to begin with, you will always have an infinite number of remaining points after each iteration. I like the idea of a point on the boundary which, after each iteration, jumps chaotically to another point on the boundary. Maybe it's in a cycle of two points, maybe three, or maybe it's part of the infinite family of points that jump forever in an infinite never-ending chain. At a boundary point, there is infinite sensitivity (we're probably very close to dividing by zero) which you cannot tell me does not mean there is an infinite family of points, which are all infinitely close together, which each bounce through completely different infinite chains of similar sorts of points. 24:00 I rathe think this is much easier and less glorious. Not "simple ideas lead to great things". There is Arnold's principle, which says: if you have something in the science named after some person, that person is likely not the inventor of that thing. The Arnold's principle, named after great soviet mathematician Vladimir Arnold, is not the exception, rather being an example of it in action. And likewise, Hamiltonian in the quantum physics, Pythagoras theorem, Newton fractal, virtually everything around us. Just a simple funny principle in action.

Richard Feynman once said: people tend to give things slightly wrong names. That was in his computer heruistics lecture, so he talked about the computer and that it is the wrong name, because actually it doesn't compute anything. It just kind of sorts things. I consider this observation as the psychological reason behind the Arnold's principle.

The most philosophically beautiful part of this video (for me) is at 17:39, when Grant says that if you'd asked him about this stuff a month ago, he would have shrugged it off.

As an educator (though I cannot hold a candle to Grant, who I consider to be one of the best educators on YouTube, if not the best), I can testify to this experience - so many times, I have learned something new in the process of preparing to teach. In fact, some of the most profound insights I've had about things have come because I was thinking of how to explain it to someone.

It's wonderful to hear that Grant experiences this too - to hear him say something which reveals that he isn't this genius with all of this stuff already stored in his head (though he is definitely a genius in more ways than one), but rather someone who discovers beautiful things and beautiful ways of visualising things because he is trying to teach it.

This, is the reason they say that the best way to learn is to teach. And the more joy and passion you bring to your teaching, the more you learn.

My intuition here is that a fractal forms at d=3 in that d*2 > 5, as opposed to d*2 < 5 for d = 2. Also, I played around with the Quaternions (H) as opposed to the Complex (C). Even weirder stuff happens. Since orders matters for both high dimensional Newton AND quaternions, the setup was Q' = Q - (f'(Q)^-1)f(Q), similar to X' = X - H^-1 ∇ f(X). Graphing and painting become weird. First off, you can't graph 4d well, .... but you can graph all the places a static 3d vector would be rotated to by the starting quaternions. Next comes convergence. You don't converge to points. You converge to spheres in 3d slices of 4d space. Insanely weird!

As I watched this video, I kept thinking about the N-body problem in physics.  It seems to me like there is a correlation between that and the content in the video. If N=2, then the solution space is perfectly predictable.  If N>2, then the end result is chaotic based on initial conditions.  The equations of gravity are the equations, and the initial location/velocities of objects are the initial input.  Seems like this would require 6 dimensions instead of the two in the complex plane in the video example.  There are many orbits that are stable (e.g., halo orbits around Lagrange points), but slight perturbations would result in unpredictable solutions.  Not sure if there is a correlation, but would be interested to hear more if there was.

To be fair, the Hamitlonian in quantum mechanics is called a Hamiltonian because of what the Hamiltonian operator actually does and how it is linked to Hamilton's work in classic mechanics. The Hamiltonian is nothing more than the function that describes sum of the energy of a system, kinetic plus potential. Hamilton had derived a form of classical mechanics that gets all of the properties of a classical system from the sum of its kinetic and potential energies and was called a Hamiltonian. In Quantum Mechanics, the Hamiltonian operator is literally just the function that would describe the total energy of the system. It is literally the exact same thing. The only different being how it is used, in Hamilton's classical mechanics it is used to obtain two first order differential equations for the equations of motion of the system, and in quantum mechanics it is used in formulating the Schrodinger Equation for a specific system since each system will have a different Hamiltonian, just like in classical mechanics.

Afaik Newton's method is also the fastest way we know to calculate many of the basis functions for even the "solvable" polynomials (to arbitrary precision, rather than e.g. 32 bits), so even solving a degree-1 polynomial (a y=mx+b line, which has x=-b/m as its solution) would use Newton's method to compute the division to arbitrary precision. So Newton's method is asymptotically the fastest way we know to do just about any calculation involving inverses (e.g. reciprocal and nth roots). Even in 32-bit arithmetic, it can be far more efficient to compute a solution to a quartic using Newton's method directly on the polynomial than to even read in the machine code description of the "analytic" solution in terms of roots and ratios.

15:38 "Repeatedly solving linear approximations" Misleading. Actually, wrong. z(n+1)=z(n) - P(z(n))/P'(z(n)) is a NONLINEAR recursion. Ok...it's linear in z(n+1), meaning, you get a UNIQUE value for z(n+1). But, P(z(n)) /P'(z(n)) is nonlinear in z(n).

Abel-Ruffini Theorem excludes formula involving EXCLUSIVELY algebraic functions: +, - , /, *, and root extraction.
It does NOT rule out transcendental functions: exp, log, sin, cos. Other theorems rule those out, but NOT Abel-Ruffini Theorem.

Newton's Fractals are a special case of "lakes of Wada", which are "are three disjoint connected open sets of the plane or open unit square with the counterintuitive property that they all have the same boundary. In other words, for any point selected on the boundary of one of the lakes, the other two lakes' boundaries also contain that point."
Of course, the number "three" can be generalized to any number >= 3.

Fascinating! Although you are wrong about your definition of unsolvability for the 5th degree polynomial and higher polynomials. According to definition unsolvability is relative to plus, minus, times, divided by, and radicals. Not relative to exp, log, sin, cos, tan etc. So these polynomials might be solvable with these transcendental functions (but probably not, except through limits). Also, we are talking about the GENERAL quintic here, there are special cases with lower degree of symmetry of their Galois group, that are indeed solvable. There are cubics and quartics with lower degree of symmetry as well. Also we can always (mostly rigourously) define ultra radicals and similar things that solve our "unsolvable" polynomials.

I did a project on these types of fractals in my complex analysis course several years ago. We also examined another root finding method, Schroeder's Method. One thing we found, which I have not been able to find other reference to, is that this other method also attracts to complex poles, something that is rather unexpected from a root finding algorithm, and something that Newton's method does not do.

Schroeder's Method: z = z0 - (f*f')/(f'^2 - f*f'')

For the "explosion" that happens at one iteration around 22:24, I found it helpful to think about the 1D case from earlier in the video again. This explosion is similar to what happened when we were hitting close to the cubic function's local minimum, where the function's derivative was incredibly shallow nearby. That makes the tangent lines nearly parallel to the X axis, which means the next iteration will need to go a very long distance before intersecting the X axis again. Points just slightly to the left of that local minimum will shoot off far to the right, and points just slightly to the right will shoot far to the left. This effectively gets us out of that local minimum's doom loop and resets our initial guess, which is why the points can eventually find a home from those new guesses.

One possible behavior that the video doesn't cover is that the iteration starts to cycle. An example is x^3-2x+2 with a starting point of x=0. In this case the points where the iteration enters the cycle forms a fourth region, in addition to the three regions corresponding to the three roots. This region will have the same boundary as the other regions, making the fractal even more complex. Surprisingly, this fourth region can have positive area, so Newton's method has a >0 probability of failing; that's a bit more serious than saying it might fail. If the area was 0 then you could hope or assume that eventually the points would escape because of rounding error. But the cycle can turn out to be attractive, meaning that small errors that creep in will not pull the points away from the cycle and toward an actual root.

I think what makes Newtons fractal significantly more simple than the mandelbrot set is the fact that for each iteration we dont care where the initial point came from. In this sense we can could describe it as a function that maps all complex numbers to the complex numbers which gets applied over and over again.
The areas where this function spreads the points over a wider area are those where the fractal changes from one solid color area to another. If you think aabout it for a second degree polynomial in the real numbers it is easy to see that the points close to the extreme point get mapped all over the numberline because of the very shallow gradient. But still all points on the right get mapped further to the right and all points on the left get mapped further to the left and of course when the gradient becomes 0 we can not map the point at all.. If you extend this to the complex numbers you still get a decision line where all points get mapped towards the side they are already on. But when you add a thrid root it will alter the gradient of the points on this decision line to be pointing more towards the third root but still get spread out over a wider area. So generally points will tend to mapped towards the roots. Now when we reverse the mapping we basically copy a part of the resulting image and place a distorted version of it where the points initially came from which basically creates many distorted copies of the voroni pattern we see with 0 iterations.

If you set it to 4 roots with the values in question being 1, -1, i, and -i a 5th color will appear in the diagram, black. Which seems to imply there are regions that never lead to a root. Why is that?

EDIT: Just confirmed it doesn't depend on those particular roots. All you need for this to happen are 2 things:

1: Each root must be equally far away from some center point.

2: If you draw a line from one root to another it must intercept and be perpendicular OR parallel to a line drawn between the other 2 roots.

I think the insolvability of the quintic is at least a bit related to this story. If all polynomials were solvable, at least in principle, numerical methods for root finding would be a lot less interesting. Given that basically all but the most simple polynomials are insolvable, it means that numerical root finding is a fundamental part of mathematics, not just the recourse of folks too lazy to solve polynomials analytically. While I don't have a strong confirmation of this, it seems like the proximity of the proof of the insolvability of the quintic to the investigation of iterated rational functions and therefore fractals (i.e. Julia) can't be a coincidence. I assume the sudden fundamental relevance of root-finding algorithms is the connection.

I've written a method of the segment class, which has derived classes arc and spiralarc, which computes the parameter (which is horizontal length along the curve, unlike a Bézier curve) of the closest point to a given point. As you said, I used the square of the distance. However, since the spiralarc (Euler spiral) cannot be expressed in closed form (for the same reason the error function can't), the square of the distance is not a polynomial function of the parameter. So I had to compute it numerically. There was a bug that, once in many millions of times, it took many minutes to compute this. The reason has to do with finite precision of floats and Cartesian lattices; I didn't figure out how to fix it until a few months ago.

Actually, there are perfectly well-defined (infinite) series solutions to the quintic. So you can use radicals and (albet infinitely many) rational operations to get all the roots of the quintic. This goes back to work of Jacob Horn (around 1889) and Richard Birkeland (around 1927) on hypergeometric series. However, the domains of convergence of these series solutions don't cover all of the coefficient space. This is yet another reason that Newton's method is so powerful and cool. It's also another reason why you shouldn't expect the convergence domains for Newton's method to be very simple.

I think @3Blue1Brown is missing this: The boundary of the fractal is the set of all points in the complex plane that will eventually land on one of the roots of the derivative of the polynomial, after some iterations. Meaning that the boundary is then the set of seed points for which Newton's method diverges. Any perturbation on the seed will make iterations be slingshot across the complex plane, letting it eventually fall on any of the roots.

For the I intuition as to why this fractal pattern happens with third order polynomials and above, I think your explosion comment is key. I suspect that the explosions must happen near a point where the derivative is zero, and that points close enough to the zero derivative point can map to any point in the complex plane that is more than some distance from the zero derivative point (sort of like how the function 1/x maps (0,1] to [1,inf) ). That means that these mapped points will then be coming from all directions and can therefore reach all zeros. But then, we can make an inductive argument and say that, points near a point that maps to a zero derivative will also have this property as they are only one step away from the explosion. This would yield an infinitely repeating pattern of small regions that can map to any zero.

For practical cases with lots of roots, to avoid landing near these fractal boundaries, a good starting point is using Residue Theorem on 1/P(x) to find regions containing just one of the roots (or some smaller set of them, if there are degenerate roots) and then apply Newton-Raphson to finish it off. Generally, 1/P(x) is well-behaved exactly where Newton-Raphson isn't. Of course, if your objective function isn't a polynomial, that can go out the window too. The way you partition the region for computing contour integrals also matters, and there can certainly be difficult cases where it's hard not to drive a boundary through a pole. So a general algorithm can get quite complex, but it usually still relies on these two methods.

9:05 If we choose the starting point to be that local minimum, the tangent line will be parallel to the x axis. All points in the vicinity would have tangents that are nearly parallel to the x axis, meaning that the intersection will be either really far to the left, or really far to the right. We can imagine one dimension higher, where it would be the local minimum of a surface, a bowl shape, at the bottom of which all tangent lines are nearly parallel to the xy plane. Any tiny deviation from the local minimum will lead the next point to be on a completely different part of the plane, which is why all the colors have to be in this 'neighborhood'.

Even though I loved the graphics, I found this one a bit more long winded than it should. The reason behind this pattern can easily been seen when we consider the Newton map on the Riemann sphere instead. Zeroes of P’ are mapped to infinity, and, in the point at infinity, all colors must converge. That means that, when we pull back that pattern, all colors must also meet along the entire pre-orbit of infinity.
What also seems really interesting, or at least piques my curiosity, is that the boundaries have a regularity to them.  In other words, the "blobs" appear to be equally spaced and shaped.

It would rather be 1) compute the enclosing path, making it a surface 2) sort all the curves into some tree structure 3) Only getting a boolean value (inside or outside the closed path), but doing it at 16 x resolution, use a algorithm that goes lines by lines, testing if you cross a curve, efficiently by exploring the tree of curve. The algoritms must be various, because in software like illustrator, you have some options and with different software you get slightly differents results, and the result is different than what you get you render at higher resolution and then average.. I just watched two seemingly unrelated videos that now seem related. I watched the "action lab" about how a mixture of alcohol and water can be partially separated (the word "partially" is important here) by mixing in salt. You can think of sodium and a chlorine ion as being "maxima" that each has to be surrounded by the positive or negative side of a water (or alcohol) molecule. The water molecule has more solutions to this problem, so more salt ions go to its side, while alcohol being more complex has fewer solutions and less salt. We always have a mixture of all three (salt, water, and alcohol), but in vastly different ratios that are separated by a clear boundary (think of it as a zero), in a way a three-dimensional fractal. The one boundary is really a complex fractal shape that extends into both regions.
